ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned to reconnect with my childhood self through an engaged sense of play. This class was great, and was such a nice respite and break from my regularly scheduled "Yale programming."
It truly was an enlightening class. Prof Chambers pushed us beyond Western Theatre, and showed us how boring the medium is.

I really expanded and strengthened my devising skills and learned a lot about clowning. I learned a lot about where tudes come from and how to set them up, and I was also pushed out of my comfort zone with improv games and clowning exercises. I also learned how to balance a stick on my hand.
I learned about improvisational techniques and exercises used in theatre. I now feel more confident using these techniques in rehearsals.  I also did research on devised theatre companies.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I would have loved if we had done some more theater games during those weeks when Dima came, but I understand that some changes in class structure had to be made.
A lot on the feet, a lot of clowning.

Greater continuity between the two halves (how to implement what we learnt before October break in our devising) would have been nice. And more chance to work each etude we presented (even if that meant we presented less often) wouldve been great. A greater awareness of consent and consent-based practices wouldve made this course better.
No weaknesses! Take this class if you have the chance, one of the most fulfilling I've taken at Yale.  Release your inner child!

I particularly loved the first couple of weeks in the course and how much the games built the ensemble feel of the class and let us just let go and have fun for once! I found that the splitting into groups and having to bring in planned-out tudes every week felt challenging in a good way, and I also think having one long research paper due at the start of the semester was really helpful, as it made finals period and preparing for final performances much less stressful. In terms of weaknesses, I do think that the lengths of time we spent hearing feedback on each tude was sometimes too long and led to a lot of us disengagingI wondered if maybe focusing on one group per class or opening up the floor to hear feedback from the students as well would've helped this. I also would've loved to do more games specifically featuring improvisation at the start of the semester!

The course was really interesting and I enjoyed getting to work with Dima Krymov. I felt like I grew as a person, not just as a theatremaker. Sometimes we spent too much time on discussing scenes rather than working on them, but overall I learned a lot as a director.

Strengths: pretty much everything, it was a very special class. 

Weaknesses: Yale

The feedback process following the etudes was sometimes long and very repetitive. I wish we could've had more time in class to workshop our etudes independently instead of Krymov kind of just telling us exactly how to fix everything during his feedback immediately following our etude. I feel like our creative expression was limited because some groups elected to just do exactly what he said instead of experimenting and landing on something they liked.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely-- everyone should take this course. David is great, and the class is quite simply just fun.
Absolutely. Might be a career defining course. One which I look at in years, thanking for guiding me into theater I aspire to make.
Yes (with caution that its a weird and wacky class and that your boundaries may be pushed further than youd like)!

I would recommend this course to any student with a strong interest in acting or directing. It definitely pushed me and caused me to build more confidence in my ability to create and perform a scene, but it was also definitely a more intensive environment than many other studio classes at Yale. It's also one of very few courses with a focus on improvisation and devising, which I feel are invaluable skills for any theater maker!
Yes, if you want to take a really unique theatre course and build your toolbox of techniques. Particularly for people who are interested in experimental theatre, this course is perfect.
